author: Kristi Turnquist | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Halloween TV 2015: 13 scary movies to watch this week
text:
If you like to get your Halloween scares in the safety of your home, TV has all sorts of spooky stuff designed to keep you glued to the couch. And nothing says Halloween like scary movies, which is why the schedule leading up to Halloween, on Saturday, Oct. 31, is crammed with opportunities to see horror classics, newer frightfests, and even some horror musicals.
Related: A guide to Halloween 2015 TV programs, including a live exorcism and the "Grimm" Season 5 premiere.
We've selected 13 seasonal favorites (technically, one of them is a trilogy) , to keep your week bubbling over with gasps, screams, and a few nervous laughs. Get ready to load up the DVR, dim the lights, and settle in for a week of terrific terror.
(Note: Many of the movies below air several times during the week; check listings if these times don't work for you.)
OCTOBER 24
"Paranormal Activity" : The 2007 "found footage," low-budget chiller about a couple who are convinced something super-creepy is going on in their house. (2 p.m. FX)
OCTOBER 25
"ParaNorman": This animated horror comedy came to us from nearby, the Hillsboro-headquarter Laika Entertainment. Marvel at the animators' expertise and follow the story of a boy who speaks to the dead, and a zombie uprising. (7 a.m. ABC Family)
"The Nightmare Before Christmas": The Halloweentown classic, featuring superb animation, and a great Danny Elfman musical score. (11 a.m. ABC Family)
OCTOBER 26
"The Cabin in the Woods": It's another bad-things-happen-in-the-forest tale, but with new cleverness, thanks to co-writers Joss Whedon ("Buffy the Vampire Slayer," "The Avengers") and Drew Goddard. (4:30 p.m. Syfy)
OCTOBER 27
"Friday the 13th": The slasher-flick original, about Camp Crystal Lake, and Jason Voorhees' revenge-fueled killing spree. (6 p.m. AMC)
OCTOBER 28
"Halloween": The first in the horror franchise featuring the crazed Michael Myers going after babysitter Laurie Strode (original scream queen Jamie Lee Curtis.) (7 p.m. AMC)
OCTOBER 29
"The Little Shop of Horrors": Roger Corman's micro-budget original, a dark comedy about a nerdy florist's assistant, and the human-craving plant he creates. A pre-fame Jack Nicholson makes a memorable appearance as a pain-loving dental patient. Feed me, Seymour! (3:45 p.m. Turner Classic Movies)
OCTOBER 30
"Dracula Has Risen From the Grave": Christopher Lee reprises his role as the bloodthirsty Count in this 1968 production from England's horror specialists, Hammer Films. (10:15 a.m. Turner Classic Movies)
"Cat People" : A horror film without much horror, but plenty of ominous mood, this 1942 classic was produced by supernatural specialist Val Lewton, and stars Simone Simon as a woman who's convinced she transforms into a big cat when her passions rise. Which makes dating tricky, as you can imagine. (5 p.m. Turner Classic Movies)
"Evil Dead" Trilogy: To get fans primed for the new "Ash vs Evil Dead," Starz is airing the original movies that gave birth to the bloody cult favorite, beginning with "The Evil Dead" at 8 p.m.; followed by "Evil Dead II" at 9:30 p.m.; and finishing with "Army of Darkness," at 10:55 p.m. Bruce Campbell hosts. (Starz)
OCTOBER 31
"A Nightmare on Elm Street": Wes Craven directed the first in another horror franchise, about teenagers killed in their dreams by the horrifying Freddy Krueger. Johnny Depp turns up, in his movie debut. (4:30 p.m. IFC)
"The Shining": Stanley Kubrick's 1980 classic still haunts anybody who's seen it. Jack Nicholson stars as the writer-turned-caretaker-turned-psychopath who turns the Overlook Hotel into a house of horrors. Oregon's Timberline Lodge does duty as the Overlook in the exterior shots. (6:30 p.m. SundanceTV)
"The Rocky Horror Picture Show": Wind up your Halloween with the cult favorite musical, starring Tim Curry, Susan Sarandon and Barry Bostwick. (Midnight HBOZone)
